details.content: Many parts of the state capital were submerged in the incessant rains that have continued to lash the state capital for more than 24 hours.

Meanwhile, the water released from Idukki Dam has been raied to 1000 cusecs.

According to a CIAL release issued at 10 am, " Kochi airport operations temporarily are suspended till 18th Saturday 2 PM since the inflow of water is still on a raising trend. We are working hard to drain out the storm water. All are requested to co-operate."

Kerala Chief Minister's press conference regarding rain havoc in the state:

From Kerala CM's press meet:

  • Scientific establishment of Community kitchens are in progress in relief camps, working of medical camps are absolutely satisfactory.
  • Two ships of Coast Guard are enroute to Ernakulam's Kochi; Two Gemini Units of Coast Guard in action, another five in standby.
  • Southern Railway will ensure adequate supply of packaged drinking water in affected areas.
  • Teams working for relief operations right now: 12 columns army, Navy's 8 helicopter and five diving teams Three teams of coast gurad and one helicopter The Chief Minsiter says that 256 persons have died due to rain havoc since May 29.

• Water level may still rise in Kuttanadu region.

  • People living in Kottayam Alappuzha Thiruvalla Chengannur need to remain alert.

  • A meeting with Telecom companies will be called to discuss about communication control with the affected areas.

  • Petroleum companies will be asked to initiate fuel availabilty since reports have come about boats running fuel.

details.title: TN CM Palaniswamy rejects Kerala CM Pinarayi Vijayan's demand to lower Mullaperiyar dam water level
details.content:
Tamil Nadu Chief Minister  Edappadi K Palaniswami on Thursday rejected the Kerala Chief Minister Pinarayi Vijayan's demand to lower the storage level of Mullaperiyar dam to 139 ft from 142ft.

Palaniswami charged that Kerala was not permitting Tamil Nadu officials to gauge the rainfall in the catchment area and Tamil Nadu officials were compelled to assess the inflow only based on the actual rate of rise in water level in the dam.

details.title: Cochin airport suspends operations till August 26
details.content:
The Cochin International Airport has suspended its operations till 2 pm on August 26 due to very high flood situation, making its key systems submerged under the water.

Due to the rising waters, "the key essential facilities like runway, taxiway and apron are under submerged condition", the airport officials said in a communique.

details.title: Jio, BSNL, Airtel Announce Free Services for Customers in Kerala
details.content: Telecom operators have announced free calls and data, extension in bill payment due dates and other relief measures for subscribers in flood-hit state of Kerala, reports PTI. Reliance Jio has announced free services for seven days while BSNL is offering unlimited free calls within its network and data services along with 100 SMS per day for a week to customers. Bharti Airtel has offered Rs 30 talk-time credit and free 1GB data for pre-paid customers for seven days.

details.title: Kochi Metro resumes services
details.content: Kochi Metro resumed train services today by 4 pm. The service will continue to run the entire stretch of 18km -- from Aluva to Maharaja's station.

details.title: PM Modi to visit Kerala on 17 August
details.content: The Prime Minister, after attending the funeral of former Prime minister AB Vajpayee, is expected to reach Kochi on Friday.

details.title: Excise duty on liquor sales hiked
details.content: The state government has hiked excise duty on liquor to mobilise funds for flood relief. Excise duty will be hiked by up to 3.5 per cent for 100 days. Rs 230 crores have been expected as additional revenue through the move. State has suffered rain-related losses to the tune of Rs 8,000 crores.

details.title: Rescue boats on their way to Chengannur
details.content: 10 Navy boats are on their way to Chengannur. Those stranded without help have been requested to flash the light from their mobiles, torches or use candles to draw attention.
